title: Moisture and Oxygen Content Sensor Suite for Nutrient Delivery Systems

abstract: Abstract         Creare proposes an innovative design for audio command, control, and communication systems. The Creare auditory system employs active noise reduction (ANR) that will reduce the harmful effects of high noise levels on personnel while simultaneously enhancing the speech intelligibility of electronic messages. Currently-available, off-the-shelf ANR audio systems provide between 10-20 dB of noise reduction for frequencies between 0.1 and 1kHz. The feedback alforithm they employ attenuates injected electronic messages as well as unwanted environmental noise and the feedback algorithm actually adds noise above 1 kHz. The Creare innovation uses a feedforward controller, which provides the ability to reduce noise by 30-40 dB over a wide electronic messages that are unaffected by the ANR algorithm. This approach will enhance audio command, control, and communication systems. During Phase I, we conclusively proved the feasibility of our innovation by conducting a system engineering analysis of the design, developing the feedforward algorithm, and fabricating and testing a laboratory bench top system. In Phase II, we will optimize the design, fabricate prototypes of the optimized design, and perform laboratory and field tests of the prototype units to verfy compliance with desired specifications.
title: Feedforward Active Noise Reduction for Effective Audio Communication Systems

abstract: Abstract         Current military aircraft oxygen supply systems are suboptimal in that they require a great deal of logistical support, do not provide a sufficient oxygen purity level for all applications, do not respond well to varying demand, are coupled directly to the engine bleed air supply, and/or present significant safety hazards. Similarly, existing fuel tank inerting systems employing molecular sieves to produce Nitrogen Enriched Air (NEA) do not produce NEA at a sufficient rate or provide for realiable operation. The opportunity is to eliminate the problems associated with these two sybsystems by developing an onboard Total Air Liquefaction System for Oxygen and Nitrogen (TALON). This system consists of a cryogenic refrigerator and two compact, lightweight, flightworthy distillation columns that provide supplies of liquid oxygen (LOX) and liquid NEA (LNEA) to several onboard dewars. Through design and hardware demonstrations of the core distillation technology, we have shown that the TALON system potentially provides many benefits to military aircraft. In the proposed Phase II project, we will demonstrate key ancillary elements ofd the proposed system including an innovative method to achieve thermal recoovery critical to efficient operation, a tilt correction scheme, and the LOX/LNEA storage and delivery systems.
title: The Storage, Delivery and Thermal Recovery System for a Total Air Liquefaction System for Oxygen and Nitrogen (TALON)

abstract: Abstract         Catheter ablation has become the treatment of choice for many types of arrhythmias largely because it is curative, safe, and relatively inexpensive. However, due to limited tools for mapping complex arrhythmias, catheter ablation is much less effective when used to treat arrhythmias that are not constrained by known anatomic barries. The goal of this research is development of a novel system for endocardial mapping, one that combines anatomical information provided by fluoroscopic images with functional information provided by intracardiac electrograms. This system will provide clinicians with a powerful tool that will assist them in accurately mapping complex arrhythmias. During Phase I, a prototype version of the system was developed and installed in a clinical setting. The prototype system demonstrated the feasibility of the concept and the primary data processing algorithms. During Phase II, a full-featured, real-time version of the system will be developed and installed in the cardiac electrophysiology laboratory. The clinical utility of the system will be evaluated during a number of arrhythmia mapping procedures and used as a basis for developing a new mapping methodology. PROPOSED COMMERCIAL APPLICATION: The primary commercial application for this work is in cardiac electrophysiology workstations. The technology developed under this program caould be incorporated in existing workstations or marketed as a stand-alone system.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: A Novel Endocardial Mapping System

abstract: Abstract         Atrial arrhythmias are extremely common and are often associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The ability to develop and prescribe new treatments for atrial arrhythmias depends on the availability of better diagnostic tools that are simple, inexpensive, and effective enough to support their use for screening large numbers of patients. During Phase I, we developed signal processing algorithms that permit noninvasive assessment of patients suffering from atrial fibrillation. T algorithms were tested on patient data and found to assist clinicians in predicting patient response to cardioversion in an attempt to terminate the arrhythmia and restore sinus rhythm. During Phase II, we will investigate alternate algorithms for identification and classification of atrial arrhythmias. Our goal is development of a tool that will allow the clinician to rapidly identify specific arrhythmias and measure the progress of individual patients through different courses of therapy. PROPOSED COMMERCIAL APPLICATION: The technology developed under this program could be used in diagnostic devices like electrocardiogram monitors.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Noninvasive Assessment of Atrial Fibrillation
